repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Third Phase of the Road
            Development Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Third Phase of the Road
            Development Program Project for Uganda were as follows:
            outcomes were moderately satisfactory; risk to development
            outcome was moderate; Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory and borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned includes: the Adaptable
            program Loan (APL) instrument cut down on the demand for
            rigorous project preparations for every Specific Investment
            Loan (SIL). Institutional reform conducted parallel to
            project implementation causes delays in program
            implementation. An important lesson learned is that
            establishment of new institutions require longer time than
            anticipated for transition, which may impact on project
            progress, and needs policy consultations and commitment as
            part of the preparatory work. Restructuring an agency at the
            same time as implementing a project is challenging and may
            cause project implementation delays. Cost of the civil works
            component both at appraisal and feasibility/detailed design
            varied substantially due to the sudden sharp rise of the
            cost of fuel, construction materials and other inputs at the
            time of bidding. Cost of the civil works component at the
            time of bidding varied substantially from that at the
            feasibility and detailed design stage due to delays in the
            procurement process of about four years.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Third Phase of the Road
            Development Program Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Third Phase of the
            Road Development Program Project for Uganda is to improve
            access to rural areas and economically productive areas and
            to progressively continue to build up sustainable road
            sector planning, design and program management capability
            including road safety management. The changes are as
            follows: (i) dropping several sub-components such as civil
            works for upgrading of about 23 km of Zirobwe-Wobulenzi
            road; rehabilitation and re-gravelling of about 91 km of
            Atiak-Moyo road; and reconstruction and upgrading of about
            57 km on Busega-Mityana road that could not be implemented
            due to a shortfall resulting from higher than anticipated
            bids received on three tendered works contracts, out of the
            seven originally planned for implementation under the
            credit; (ii) re-allocating the amounts in category 1 (b) for
            reconstruction and upgrading of Busega-Mityana road of SDR
            16.53 million to category 1 (a) to meet the shortfall on
            upgrading Soroti-Lira road (125 km) and
            Kampala-Gayza-Zirobwe road (44 km); due to the above and due
            to the fact that the financing agreement was amended (April
            25, 2007) to allow 100 percent IDA financing of civil works
            and consultancy services under the project resulting in cost
            increases; and (iii) extending the closing date by 22 months
            from December 31, 2009 to October 30, 2011. Due to initial
            procurement delays, the last of three contracts for
            upgrading of Dokolo-Lira road contract will end on November
            30, 2011. Thus, the extension will allow for completion of
            the contract and defects liability period and implementation
            of the Technical Assistance (TA) support to the Ministry of
            Works and Transport (MoWT) and Uganda National Roads
            Authority (UNRA). The changes and reallocation will help
            finance the deficit on the on-going contracts, caused by
            higher bid prices than originally envisaged at appraisal,
            resulting from increases in the costs of construction inputs
            in both local and international markets. The changes will
            also take into account the initial delays in the procurement
            of works.

repnme.cdata!:
Uganda - Third Phase of the Road
            Development Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the Road
            Development Program for Uganda is to improve access to rural
            areas and economically productive areas, and to
            progressively continue to build up sustainable road sector
            planning, design and program management capability including
            road safety management. The project has the following six
            components: (1) There is a major cotton processing facility
            in Lira and the prospect of rehabilitating the factory would
            increase substantially  the cotton production. Upgrading the
            road would also extend the paved road network to the North,
            providing for significant improvements to road transport
            services between Kampala and the North and between the
            North, the border regions of Malaba and Busia, and on to the
            East African seaboard. (2) The facilities of the Ministry of
            Works, Housing and Communication (MOWHC) date largely from
            the colonial era. It is proposed to build the Headquarters
            on MOWHC land near the Central Mechanical Workshop in
            Kampala. (3) The road construction covers the estimates
            costs for the supervision cervices of the construction of
            project roads. (4) Consultants services are being undertaken
            under Road Sector Institutional Support Technical Assistance
            Project (RSISTAP) for the execution of full feasibility
            studies on the upgrading to National Road Standards of a
            number of District Road Sections as National Roads. (5)
            Consultants services will be procured in 2004 with the
            feasibility studies being completed in 2005. (6) The need to
            consolidate the institutional reform process initiated under
            the Transport Rehabilitation Project (TRP), and RSISTAP has
            been identified in the recently completed Uganda Road Agency Study.
